title: Problem-Solving Strategy: Determining Continuity at a Point
text: Step 1: check to see if f(a) is defined. If f(a) is undefined, we need go no further. The function is not continuous at a. If f(a) is defined, continue to step $$2$$. Step 2: Compute $$\lim_{x\toa} f(x)$$. In some cases, we may need to do this by first computing $$\lim_{x\toa-} f(x)$$ and /lim{x,a+,f(x)}. If $$\lim_{x\toa} f(x)$$ does not exist (that is, it is not a real number), then the function is not continuous at a and the problem is solved. If $$\lim_{x\toa} f(x)$$ exists, then continue to step $$3$$. Step 3: Compare f(a) and $$\lim_{x\toa} f(x)$$. If $$\lim_{x\toa} f(x)$$ does not equal to f(a), then the function is not continuous at a. If $$\lim_{x\toa} f(x)=f(a)$$, then the function is continuous at a.

If , the limit as x 	oa, of f of x  does not equal to f(a), then the function is not continuous at a. If , the limit as x 	oa, of f of x is equal to f of a , then the function is continuous at a.

title: Determine f(3)
